a b s t r a c t
A series of nano-Mg(OH)2/graphene (Gr) composites was synthesized via simple hydrothermal method using MgSO4 7H2O and graphene oxide (GO) as precursors, hydrazine hydrate as additive. Linear sweep voltammetry tests showed that the 2# composite synthesized from 50 wt.% MgSO4 7H2O and 50 wt.% GO with a surface density of 1.5 mg cm 2 exhibited the best catalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction. The 2# composite was utilized as the cathodic catalyst in a microbial electrolysis cell (MEC) to facilitate hydrogen production. In the MEC tests, the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode was comparable with the Pt/C cathode in terms of current densities and energy efficiency. The hydrogen recovery, cathodic hydrogen recovery and hydrogen production rate obtained with nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr MEC were 71 ± 12%, 83 ± 9% and 0.63 ± 0.11 m3 H2 m 3 d 1, slightly higher than those obtained with the Pt/C cathode MEC. The nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode exhibited good stability, and it was inexpensive (less than 1.7% of the cost of the Pt/C cathode). These results demonstrated that the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composite was an effective HER catalyst because of its good catalytic capacity, durability, and low price.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen is considered the most important energy carrier and fuel of the future because of its high energy density and zeroemission properties. Microbial electrolysis cell (MEC) is a promising new technology for hydrogen production from waste biomass. By utilizing anode microorganism activity, MEC can produce hydrogen gas with smaller voltages (as low as 0.2 V) than those required for electrolytic hydrogen production (P1.23 V) [1–3].
The cathode, where hydrogen is produced, is one of the most important parts of the MEC [4]. A suitable cathode must have the following properties: large active surface area, good electrocatalytic activity, electrochemical stability, electrical conductivity, and low hydrogen over-potential [5]; a long electrode life is also desirable. The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on bare cathodes (such as carbon electrodes) occurs very slowly because of the high over-potential of the system. Thus, a catalyst is necessary. Platinum is commonly used as a catalyst because of its low free energy difference in the initial Volmer reaction, Tafel reaction, and/or Heyrovsky reaction [6]. However, the high cost of platinum

limits its application [7]. Platinum can also be poisoned by chemicals, such as sulfide [1] or phosphate anions [8]. Thus, determining an alternative to Pt catalysts to commercialize the MEC system is very important. Different materials, such as stainless steel [9,10], molybdenum disulfide [11], nickel and Ni-alloy [12–14], carbon/ iron-based nanorods [3], and tungsten carbide [15], among others, have been tested as cathodes in MEC.
Magnesium hydroxide is usually used as a flame retardant in polymers [16,17] and adsorbent to remove dyes in water [18]. Salleh et al. [19] recently determined that the kinetics of HER on Mg(OH)2-covered Mg surfaces was significantly higher than that on pristine Mg surfaces and that the Mg(OH)2 covered surface could enhance the self-dissociation of water. Thus we speculated that Mg(OH)2 exhibits catalytic activity for HER. However, the conductivity of Mg(OH)2 is poor because of its supposed insulation. To increase the electrical conductivity of Mg(OH)2, the compound must be combined with some conductive materials.
Graphene, which was discovered in 2004, has gained significant research attention because of its high electrical conductivity, large surface area, excellent electrocatalytic activities, and low production costs [20,21]. Compared with the conventional carbon materials, such as activated carbon and CNTs, graphene provides significant advantages as a catalyst support material. Xia et al. [23] demonstrated that the nanostructured MnO2/graphene composite exhibited excellent catalytic activity for oxygen reduction in MFC. To our best knowledge, using Mg(OH)2/Gr composite as a catalyst for HER in MEC is rarely reported.
In this study, a series of nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composites was synthesized through the hydrothermal method. Characterizations of the catalysts were performed through scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The HER activity of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composites catalyst was investigated through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and Tafel analysis. Catalytic performance was further evaluated in an MEC with a nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr catalyst carbon paper cathode in terms of current densities, coulomb efficiency, hydrogen production rate and recovery, and cathodic hydrogen recovery. For comparison, platinized carbon paper (Pt/C, 0.5 mg cm 2) and unmodified carbon paper (CP) cathodes were also investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Catalyst synthesis
sections.text: Catalyst synthesis was carried out in two steps. First, graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized from natural graphite by adopting the modified Hummers method [24]. Second, four nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composites (identified as 1#, 2#, 3#, and 4#) were synthesized as follows: A specific amount of GO (Table 1) was added to distilled water. The solution was vibrated in an ultrasonic bath for 1 h to obtain a homogeneous solution, and then a specific amount of MgSO4 7H2O was dissolved in the solution. After sonicating the solution for 0.5 h, 2 mL of hydrazine hydrate (HHA) was added to the solution. The solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflonlined stainless steel autoclave after sonication for 5 min. The hydrothermal reaction was carried out at 180 C for 12 h. After the reaction was completed, the black precipitates were collected through centrifugation, washed several times with deionized water, and dried at 60 C in a vacuum for 12 h. The material ratios are shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Cathode electrode preparation
sections.text:
The carbon paper electrodes were modified with nano-Mg (OH)2/Gr composites. An unmodified electrode was used as a control. Each electrode had a projected surface area of 4 cm2. For modification, 8 mg of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composite was mixed with 0.5 mL of absolute ethyl alcohol. The mixture was sonicated for 0.5 h to obtain a homogeneous suspension. The suspension was applied to the carbon paper uniformly using a pipette (both sides were coated). After drying in air, 10 lL of Nafion solution (0.02 wt.%) was dropped on carbon paper. Finally, the modified carbon paper was dried in air. The final loading quantity of the modifying material was 1 mg cm 2. The best nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composite was selected through LSV. sections.heading: 2.3. MEC construction and operation
sections.text:
Single-chamber MECs with an operating volume of 80 mL were utilized in this study. The anode was made of carbon felt (2 4 1 cm3) initially inoculated in the double-chamber MFCs. The distance between the anode and cathode was 1.5 cm. A total of 20 mL of a pre-acclimated suspension of bacteria solution from MFCs that were run for more than 3 months was also injected into the MEC. The nutrient solution consisted of 100 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7), KCl 130 mg L 1, NH4Cl 310 mg L 1, trace mineral element solution 20 mL and NaAc 3H2O 2000 mg L 1 (the organic substrate).
The MEC was operated in batch mode at room temperature (20 C). A power source (HB 17301 SL; Hossoni, Inc., China) provided an external voltage of 0.7 V. The end of the batch was determined by the end of the gas production and the sharp decrease in current production. After each cycle, the 50 mL nutrient solution was replaced and the electrodes were exposed to air for 20–30 min and sparged with nitrogen gas for 15 min [25]. To prevent microbes from growing on the unmodified carbon paper, the control carbon paper cathode was ultrasonically washed after every batch. All batch experiments were run in duplicate.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurement and analysis
sections.text:
The morphologies and chemical composition of the composites were investigated by SEM (JSM-7001F, JEOL, Japan), TEM (G2 F20, FEI, USA), and XRD (XRD-6000, Shimadzu LabX, Japan). An electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research, USA) with a three-electrode arrangement, including a working electrode (cathode), a counter electrode (platinum electrode), and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used for LSV. The LSV tests were conducted in a separate beaker containing N2-saturated phosphate buffer solution (100 mM PBS, pH = 7.0) over a range of 0.9 V to 0.5 V at a scan rate of 10 mV/s. Tafel analysis was performed using the methods reported by Jadhav et al. [26] to determine the electrode kinetics.
The current of the MEC was recorded every 30 min using a digital multimeter (UNI-T 803; Uni-Trend Electronics Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China). Gas production in the MEC was measured by water replacement utilizing a graduated flask. The gas composition was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The effluent NaAc concentrations were determined with a gas chromatograph (model 6890NT, Agilent Inc., USA) equipped with a flame ionization detector. Gas production performance was characterized by calculating hydrogen recovery, hydrogen production rate, and energy recovery (electrical and overall energy) as previously described [1].

As the MgSO4 7H2O proportion in the mixture decreased, only four and three diffraction peaks appeared on the 3# and 4# curves, respectively. The heights of these peaks also decreased further. In Fig. 1, a broad diffraction peak appeared at 2h values of 25 , and the peak height increased with the GO proportion in the mixture. This peak was the diffraction peak of amorphous carbon and indicated that the GO was reduced to graphene by HHA.
The SEM and TEM images of 2# composite are presented in Fig. 2. Fig. 2A shows that some flower-like Mg(OH)2 was attached to the surface of the graphene sheet. Pure Mg(OH)2 exhibits a special 2D nanostructure [18]. In this study, MgSO4 dissociates into ions and GO contains hydroxyl groups. The interaction between positively charged Mg2+ and negatively charged GO results in assembling Mg2+ on GO [27]. The aggregation of Mg(OH)2 nanosheets was prevented, and the Mg(OH)2 morphology evolved from a 2D compact structure to a 3D flower-like superstructure. In Fig. 2B, the Mg(OH)2 was loaded on the surface of graphene and the diameter of the smallest Mg(OH)2 particle was 4 nm. The periodic atom arrangement of the Mg(OH)2 was clearly illustrated in Fig. 2C, and the in-plane lattice constant was 0.23 nm. The results in Fig. 2C demonstrated that the Mg(OH)2 presented a crystal form.

The control carbon paper cathode exhibited a low current density, thereby indicating that the carbon paper without any catalyst showed minimal activity for proton reduction. The carbon paper cathode modified by the 2# composite demonstrated a current density that was significantly higher than those of the other three cathodes and comparable with Pt/C cathode. For example, the 2# cathode exhibited a current density of 94.85 A m 2 at a potential of 0.89 V (vs. SCE), which was much higher than the corresponding current densities of the 1# ( 49.48 A m 2), 3# ( 33.83 A m 2), and 4# ( 27.10 A m 2) cathodes. This phenomenon may be explained by the following reasons: Mg(OH)2 exhibits catalytic activity for HER but shows poor conductivity. When the ratio of Mg(OH)2 in the composite is large, the number of active sites on the electrode surface is adequate but the conductivity of the composite is poor. Decreasing the Mg(OH)2 content appropriately could improve conductivity. Thus, current density increases despite the number of active sites decreasing. However, the current density decreased as the ratio of Mg(OH)2 further declined. Results indicated that the 2# composite showed the best catalytic activity for H+ reduction compared with the other composites studied [3]. Thus, the 2# composite was used to investigate the effect of varying catalyst loading amounts on catalytic activity.
The2#compositewasapplied at loads of 0.5, 1, 1.5, or 2 mg cm 2. As shown in Fig. 3B, the current density increased drastically below 0.74 V as the catalyst loading increased from 0.5 mg cm 2 to 1 mg cm 2. For example, current density increased from 35.08 A m 2 to 98.00 A m 2 at 0.9 V, and from 30.08 A m 2 to 54.40 A m 2 at 0.8 V. Increasing the catalyst loading from 1 mg cm 2 to 1.5 mg cm 2 did not significantly affect the current density in the lowpotential region below 0.84 V.However, current density significantly increased within the 0.84 to 0.1 V potential region. The hydrogen evolution overpotential also decreased as catalyst loading increased from 1 mg cm 2 to 1.5 mg cm 2. Compared with Pt/C cathode (Fig. 3A), the current density of 1.5 mg cm 2 catalyst was higher within the scope of 0.4 to 0.3 V. Subsequently, current density obviously decreased as the catalyst loading was increased from 1.5 mg cm 2 to 2 mg cm 2.
Tafel analysis was used to determine the electrode kinetics. According to the Tafel plots showed in Supporting Information (Fig. S1), the cathode exchange current density, i0 (A cm 2), were calculated and listed in Table S1. The i0 of cathode loaded with 2# 1.5 mg cm 2 catalyst was 1.78 A m 2 (the standard deviation s = 0.07), slightly lower than that of Pt/C cathode (2.10 A m 2, s = 0.08), and higher than those of other cathodes. The Tafel analysis was repeated 3 times for every cathodes, and the standard deviation for multiple testes was below 0.08. The relative standard deviation (RSD) of multiple testes was below 5.7%, indicating good reproducibility of these curves.
These results indicated that the optimal cathode was the 2# composite cathode at a loading of 1.5 mg cm 2.

sections.heading: 3.3. MEC tests
sections.text:
Based on the LSV tests and Tafel analysis, application of the 2# composite cathode at a loading of 1.5 mg cm 2 was selected for additional tests in an MEC; the performance of this MEC was compared with that of other MECs with Pt/C (0.5 mg cm 2) and control carbon paper cathodes. When 0.7 V was applied to the MEC, a profile of current production was obtained in batch operation mode. The current rapidly increased after the nutrient solution was replaced, reached relatively stable values, and rapidly decreased because of nutrient solution depletion (Fig. 4). The average current density for those cathodes in the MECs was 9.21 A m 2 for nanoMg(OH)2/Gr, 9.24 A m 2 for Pt/C and 3.05 A m 2 for CP. In the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 5th, 6th, and 7th cycles, the peak current density of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC was lower than that of the Pt/C cathode MEC. However, in the 8th cycle, the peak current density of the former was 17.78 A m 2, 2.80 A m 2 higher than that of the latter. In the 9th cycle, the peak current density of the former was 18.30 A m 2, 1.75 A m 2 higher than that of the latter. The peak current density of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC increased gradually with increasing running time, indicating the good stability of the catalyst. The peak current density of Pt/C cathode MEC decreased in the last three cycles, a result that may be attributed to Pt poisoning by phosphate ions [8].
Hydrogen production at all of the cathodes was monitored, and the energy efficiencies obtained are summarized in Table 2. Both nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr and Pt/C cathodes MEC exhibited similar coulombic efficiency (RCE), electrical energy efficiency (gW) and overall energy efficiency (gW+S), substantially higher than that obtained with the CP cathode MEC. During the experiments, the gas produced was collected and its composition was analyzed (Fig. 5). The gas produced by the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC in one cycle was 79 ± 7 mL, 21.0% higher than that by Pt/C cathode MEC (66 ± 3 mL). The CP cathode MEC produced the least amount of gas, and only 9.6 ± 0.7 mL was collected at the end of each cycle. The composition of the gas produced by the CP cathode MEC included H2 (42.5 ± 0.8%), CH4 (4.8 ± 0.6%), and CO2 (52.8 ± 0.1%). The H2 and CO2 compositions of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC totaled 63 ± 5% and 33 ± 3%; these values were similar with those produced by the Pt/C cathode MEC (60 ± 4% and 28 ± 5%, respectively). The CH4 percentage produced by the Pt/C cathode MEC (12 ± 1%) was higher than that produced by the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC (4 ± 2%). The reason might be that: At the last period of each cycle, the current density of Pt/C cathode MEC was lower than that of nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC, and the hydrogen production rate of former was lower than that of latter. Most CH4 was produced by hydrogenotrophic methanogens at the end of a batch cycle when hydrogen and carbon dioxide gases were present at the greatest concentrations [28]. The hydrogenotrophic methanogens converted part of the H2 produced at the cathode into methane. The CH4 content produced in this work was higher than that produced in other studies when the applied voltage is 0.7 V. This might be due to the lower current than the other studies [28] or the bacterial species sourced differently from other studies.
The experiments were carried out for 2 months. During the test duration, the performance of the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode remained stable. After the experiments, the cathodeswere removed from the MEC and observed by SEM (the figure was not given). No bacteria grew on the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode, which implied that Mg(OH)2 exhibited antibacterial activity and could inhibit bacterial growth on the cathode surface [29]. However, anodic microbial growth and bacterial activity were not inhibited because of the non-contact with Mg(OH)2. While some bacteria were found on the Pt/C cathode, part of themmight be hydrogenotrophic
methanogens [28,30] that consumed H2 to produce CH4. This might be the reason that why the current of Pt/C cathode MEC produced was the same, but the amount of hydrogen measured was less than the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC. A significant advantage of using nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode is its low cost. Based on current purchase prices, we estimated that the raw materials needed to prepare a nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode (2 2 cm2) cost less than ¥1, whereas a Pt/C cathode (0.5 mg cm 2, 2 2 cm2) costs approximately ¥60.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: A series of nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composites was prepared using a simple hydrothermal method. The results of the LSV test indicated that when the mass ratio of GO and MgSO4 7H2O was 1:1, the synthetic composite exhibited the best catalytic activity for H+ reduction. The optimal load on the carbon paper electrode was 1.5 mg cm 2. SEM images of the #2 composite showed flowerlike Mg (OH)2 attached to the surface of the graphene sheet. The results of the MEC tests indicated that the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode MEC performed better than Pt/C cathode MEC during H2 production and that the former was comparable with the latter in terms of current density and energy efficiency. The nano-Mg (OH)2/Gr cathode exhibited good stability and was inexpensive. Thus, the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composite is a potential HER catalyst with good catalytic capacity, durability, and low price.

metadata.abstractText: A series of nano-Mg(OH)2/graphene (Gr) composites was synthesized via simple hydrothermal method using MgSO4 7H2O and graphene oxide (GO) as precursors, hydrazine hydrate as additive. Linear sweep voltammetry tests showed that the 2# composite synthesized from 50 wt.% MgSO4 7H2O and 50 wt.% GO with a surface density of 1.5 mg cm 2 exhibited the best catalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction. The 2# composite was utilized as the cathodic catalyst in a microbial electrolysis cell (MEC) to facilitate hydrogen production. In the MEC tests, the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode was comparable with the Pt/C cathode in terms of current densities and energy efficiency. The hydrogen recovery, cathodic hydrogen recovery and hydrogen production rate obtained with nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr MEC were 71 ± 12%, 83 ± 9% and 0.63 ± 0.11 m H2 m 3 d , slightly higher than those obtained with the Pt/C cathode MEC. The nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr cathode exhibited good stability, and it was inexpensive (less than 1.7% of the cost of the Pt/C cathode). These results demonstrated that the nano-Mg(OH)2/Gr composite was an effective HER catalyst because of its good catalytic capacity, durability, and low price. 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
